title: ‘All Mirrors’ by Angel Olsen Review: A Surprising Turn
text:
When an indie rock artist reaches a certain level of success, the next step is often a foray into pop. Following breakthrough records, acts including Mitski, St. Vincent and Vampire Weekend teamed with high-profile collaborators and tested mainstream waters. Such moves aren’t hard to fathom—it’s a challenge to give your music a new shape and try for new listeners. But there’s something to be said for the bold aesthetic left-turn that comes out of nowhere, a move that seems to satisfy a creative need more than a commercial one.

“All Mirrors,” the fourth album from Angel Olsen, out Oct. 4 on Jagjaguwar, is such a work. The singer and songwriter’s last collection of new material, the acclaimed 2016 set “My Woman,” would seem to have positioned her nicely for broader success. While lo-fi folk and creaky countrified rock defined her early music, “My Woman” had propulsive hooks and a sparkling pop sheen. And earlier this year, Ms. Olsen appeared on “True Blue,” a terrific collaboration with Mark Ronson from the noted producer’s recent LP, which nearly sounded ready for radio.

But “All Mirrors” is something else entirely—a challenging and intense art-pop offering unconcerned with trends. Produced by Ms. Olsen and John Congleton, who worked with her on 2014’s “Burn Your Fire for No Witness,” the record’s defining characteristic is the strings that dominate the mix and seem to cover her voice in a dark mist. The tension between her distinctive tone and the glissando-rich arrangements by Ben Babbitt and Jherek Bischoff brings to mind ambitiously orchestrated albums by artists like Radiohead, Kate Bush and Mercury Rev, and Ms. Olsen makes the most of the grand setting.

“Lark” begins the record with a cluster of dissonance, as if tuning up for what’s to come, and Ms. Olsen then enters in her quietest vocal mode, a hushed tone that hints at the potential for violence. Experience with her dynamic song structures suggests the muted opening will give way to a dramatic peak, but when it does the sheer intensity of the explosion is still shocking. “Hiding out inside my head it’s me again it’s no surprise I’m on my own now,” she sings over pounding drums, her urgency amplified by the dozen instruments surrounding her.

Ms. Olsen approaches singing almost like an actor, with a new tone to pair with each emotional development. On “Impasse,” she sounds drugged and wounded before coming to life later in the song, and a similar feeling of desolation marks the vocal on “Tonight,” on which she sings of forgetting about a lover to find herself. While the lyrics throughout the album aren’t especially quotable and don’t jump off the page, they work beautifully in context, each vowel and consonant articulated for maximum effect. “Spring” is a nice example of Ms. Olsen’s phrasing mastery, as she sings “Show me a love that won’t ever leave / Or look to another one to deceive,” the stress on the middle syllable of “another” adding a twist of anticipation.

A few tunes hint at atmospheric dream-pop, and suggest a road not taken. With some adjustments, the title track could have been a percolating dance-pop number, but Ms. Olsen slows it down and draws it out, allowing its observations about growing old and losing your sense of self to sink deeper. “New Love Cassette” begins with a wobbly synth bass and Ms. Olsen singing in her lower register, as if directly into your ear, and for a moment suggests something like a slow-burn LCD Soundsystem ballad. But then it gets weirder as it goes, with fierce double-bass flourishes and a drone that fills the song like water seeping into a ship.

The album droops slightly in its final quarter—“Summer” and “Endgame” are in line with the other songs tonally, but aren’t as powerful as what came before—until it ends on a strong note with “Chance.” Here, the strings have moved from fraught expressionism to an arrangement that evokes the twinkling childlike wonder of a midcentury Disney score, and as if emerging from a dark cave and stepping into the light.

“All Mirrors” is not an easy album to listen to—it doesn’t lend itself to passive consumption. You have to absorb it on its own terms or not at all, and that’s exciting. Ms. Olsen has said she’ll release the songs from “All Mirrors” in another format next year with just her voice and guitar. It’s hard to say how this minimalist approach will work given the overwhelming nature of the sonics here, but it’s an intriguing thought that underscores her adventurousness and willingness to surprise.

—Mr. Richardson is the Journal’s rock and pop music critic. Follow him on Twitter @MarkRichardson.
description: Instead of aiming for mainstream popularity following earlier successes, the indie artist has delivered a challenging and intense art-pop offering unconcerned with trends.
